comment.body: Or even make it configurable.
This sounds very interesting. Are there any apps around that use the aDTN protocol?
Thanks, mate!
PyBitmessage cannot use `keys.dat` if that file is still encrypted, so if PyBitmessage can read the file, so can an attacker.

As for other files: A password manager (say, https://www.passwordstore.org/ ) can decrypt the single password you need and write it to the console, and still keep everything encrypted. Something like that could be a solution for other files than `keys.dat`.

Encrypting your harddrive is not to protect you from the operating system (heck, you need to decrypt the filesystem for the o/s to use it), it's to protect the contents of the disk if Putin's death squad steals your harddrive.

You can just encrypt the “secret” files with gpg or similar and no spyware can get to their contents.
You need to be more specific if you want specific solutions.

@Kaffie: the sweet thing is that namecoin has multiple namespaces. While the “d/” namespace is used for .bit domains, the “id/” namespace is used for, well, IDs. There are a few examples in a somewhat unrelated post: http://127.0.0.1:43110/todayilearned.bit/?Post:8

(What a pity markdown links don't work here…)
I was wondering: Since each zite has a public/private keypair, couldn't an ID be as simple as signing “something” with one of your private zeronet keys?

@Bashrc: Yes, you're right. It would definitely be good to have an ID system that works with mesh networks (and having said that, it would also be nice if Zeronet were IPv6 aware so that it could run on e.g. Hyperboria/cjdns).

You are right. Although I don't understand why, since the last transaction was on August 7, the effective balance on your account is zero and so you cannot forge.
In reality it doesn't mean anything. It would be extremely unlike that you could forge anything with the small amount of NXT on your account. For the past couple of year an account of mine that holds a considerably bigger amount of NXT has forged only some 300 NXT altogether. It generally forges around a block a day, but many blocks do not hold a transaction so no fee is paid to the forger.

The zone file is a binary blob.

$ file /usr/share/zoneinfo/Europe/Copenhagen
/usr/share/zoneinfo/Europe/Copenhagen: timezone data, version 2, 7 gmt time flags, 7 std time flags, no leap seconds, 134 transition times, 7 abbreviation chars

@Musickiller: it's not a text file, that's why you see that dirt in your terminal.

Try “hexdump -C /usr/share/zoneinfo/Europe/Moscow”
@Musickiller: you should definitely not waste the arch devs' time by reporting a non-bug. ;)

When you cat a binary file, there might be all sort of characters between 0 and 255. Some of those chars might be control chars, which is why your terminal end up looking like that. Try cat'ing any file from /usr/bin and your will end up with a similar result. Just use “reset” if it happens and get on with your life.
== if you type “reset” you font will be “unbroken”.
@Musickiller: perhaps those terminals have a different background.
See e.g. https://mosh.org/#techinfo (the 8 screenshots a bit further down).

$ pacman -Ss nvidia- | grep installed
extra/nvidia-dkms 370.23-1 [installed]
extra/nvidia-libgl 370.23-1 [installed]
extra/nvidia-settings 370.23-1 [installed]
extra/nvidia-utils 370.23-1 [installed]
My card didn't work with nouveau so I chose nvidia instead. But I had to disable acceleration, AFAIK. Hm…, I can't find that now.

@Musickiller: The only line I have in that conf is:

HOOKS="base udev autodetect modconf keymap block encrypt filesystems keyboard fsck"

The only kernel params I have are “rw nvidia-drm.modeset=1”

(And I don't know what that nvidia param mean)

And I have

# causes loadavg > 1.0
blacklist rtsx_usb_ms
blacklist memstick

in /etc/modprobe.d/00-blacklist.conf

@Musickiller: One of the nvidia things loaded the rtsx_usb_ms and the memstick modules. Now, there's a bug somewhere that makes the loadavg always have a minimum of 1 (normal minimum is 0) when those modules are loaded. I don't seem to need those modules so I have blacklisted them and now my loadavg can go to zero.

@Musickiller: My CPU has 4 cores. If 1 of them is constantly being used by a buggy module there's only 3 cores left. Why should I be satisfied with 75% CPU when  disabling 2 buggy modules can give me 100%?

@Musickiller: yes: when a new kernel version is installed, the nvidia module is recompiled automatically using the DKMS system.

https://wiki.archlinux.org/index.php/Dynamic_Kernel_Module_Support
@Mikhailobv: Then we would all have to install RethinkDB also, wouldn't we?

I don't believe that bug has been patched. People have been complaining about them for years, according to Google. It would be strange if someone woke up within the past 2½ months and decided to look at that bug. But it's unimportant for me. I just ban those two modules and everything's fine. If you're not bit by the bug, that's fine too.

On Arch, /bin is just a symlink to /usr/bin:

$ ls -ld /{,usr/}bin
lrwxrwxrwx 1 root root     7 Sep 30  2015 /bin -> usr/bin
drwxr-xr-x 5 root root 94208 Aug 25 15:07 /usr/bin

Still, I don't think the installation scripts should attempt to remove the kbmsgr dir at all.

Procmail has has nothing to do with turning your machine into a post-machine. Kbmsgr  now depends on the lockfile utility from the procmail package, not the postfix package.

I prefer if you open issues on Github instead of here and on kbmsgr itself. I like to keep thing in one place.

I can see the “delete a couple of symbols” bug, but I don't see how I can fix it: It's really a bug in bash's builtin command “read”.
If you keep your lines shorter it won't happen. ;)
@Musickiller: “procmail” has “default-mta” or “mail-transport-agent” or “fetchmail” as a RECOMMEND, not as a DEPEND: http://packages.ubuntu.com/precise/procmail
@Musickiller: you mean postfix, don't you? Maybe the default Ubuntu policy is to “Yes, please install all recommended packages in addition to the required packages!”?
@Musickiller: AFAIK, you can uninstall postfix. But kbmsgr now depends on lockfile, which is a part of the procmail package, so you can't uninstall procmail.

The hard way:

1) Download https://prerelease.keybase.io/keybase_amd64.deb
2) Extract with “ar x keybase_amd64.deb”
3) cd /
4) sudo tar xvf /path/to/data.tar.xz
5) sudo strip /usr/bin/keybase /usr/bin/kbfsfuse
6) Profit!!!

@Musickiller: If you use the hard way to install it, you use the hard way to remove it: manually. or you can list the tarball to see which files to delete.

You can probably install any debian package like that, but it would be easier if you find a package to convert .deb to Arch package format. I know there is a util, but I forgot the name.

I like the idea of PoW/hashcash and PoC (although I don't know how to implement the latter). Decentralized CAPTCHAs is also a good idea.
I'm not sure I like the idea of centralized approval, although I recognize a zite owner's right to ban anyone from posting on their zite.
About the CAPTCHA: it could be a simple math problem, like adding two random integers.

@Dergatt: How about the “Are you a robot?” CAPTCHAs that are often seen these days? In most cases all you have to do is click continue/submit.

Though: I assume most people are using the webui to post on Zeronet, and so automated postings are less of a concern. Thus my priority would also be PoW,

> This program is free software; you can redistribute it and/or modify it under the terms of the GNU General Public License as published by the Free Software Foundation; either version 2 of the License, or (at your option) any later version.

Doesn't that mean that I can switch my own code as I see fit and redistribute other's code under GPL3?

Curious here: Is that series worth my while?
@Nofish: That's a *very* bad idea, IMHO. Having an account on a third party social network should *not* be a requirement for posting to Zeronet. Hashcash/PoW is a much better idea.

@Nofish: I think the PoW should be targeted not at account creation, but at posting — like e.g. Bitmessage and MORPHiS do, to mention a few that I can remember off the top of my head. I'm aware that each of us has different CPU (or even GPU) capabilities, but I think a PoW requirement is still infinitely better than requiring an account on a third party website.

@Nofish: I beg to differ: I would definitely stop using Zeronet if a Twitter or Facebook account were a requirement. But let's leave it at that…

What happened to the CAPTCHA idea then?

Perhaps the best solution would be to be able to mute certain accounts. We already have the posibility of not subscribing to a spammer's zite or profile, but being able to mute could make e.g. the firehose useful even in the midst of a spammer attack.
@Nofish: I was talking about CAPTCHAs for posting.
@Nofish: so is the spam.
@AntiGNU: it could be simple math problems: what is 11 + 2

Being able to mute certain accounts saves us from requiring a Twitter/Facebook account, it doesn't rely on a tyranny of the majority to upvote a user or their posts, it doesn't prevent anybody from posting to their heart's content, it doesn't censor anything, but it does enable each individual user to make invisible posts that they don't want to see or engage in.

@AntiGNU: the check could be built into Zeronet js. Yes, I'm aware that a spammer could alter the source so that a CAPTCHA check always returns “PASS”. There will always be bright heads around. And I'm not really for any solution that restricts what people can do (that's why solutions like third party accounts, PoW, reputation, {up,down}voting, and whatnot all sucks), I'm merely picking my brains here.

@AntiGNU: You're right, I'm also only talking about merger sites here. I couldn't care less what kind of restrictions people are putting on their individual zites. When it comes to muting, I'm still pretty convinced that spammers will stop spamming if they find that nobody read or comments on their posts. I'm also pretty convinced that if we see restrictions enforced on the major hubs, then we'll end up with a one-hub-per-user situation.

May I add here that MORPHiS development is ongoing. People interested in learning more about — or contributing to — MORPHiS should join the #morphis channel on Freenode IRC. Sam's wife/widow Mel and his brother Peter are also present there.

The source code has been secured. Before developing on the source code a new infrastructure is being discussed, since there are no longer access to the servers Sam set up.

While I haven't read the paper, one question immediately comes to mind when I read a statement like the one above: Are we looking at “books ⇒ mortality” or “mortality ⇒ books”?

@Antilibrary: I'm, not sure I agree. It does say that _book reading did not mediate the relationship between cognition and survival_, but it could simply be that the personality type that lives longer is also a personality type that reads books. Like a coupled gene.
